editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

figure.figDesc: portrait, possibly of Sir William Lower

div.head: To her MAJESTY THE QUEEN OF BOHEMIA.
div.p:
Were I not fully perſwaded that this Dramatick Piece in the Original is one of the beſt
that hath been preſented upon the French Stage, I ſhould not have preſumed to offer the Copy to the beſt of Queens, and indeed the moſt Juditious of Women: If I have failed in my judgment of the Authours work, I am indiſputably right in the Character of my Patroneſs: Your Majeſties goodneſs in pardoning this preſumption, and in approving the Plot and Language of the Play in my Verſion,
hath begotten this future ambition in me, to publish it under the favour of your Royall protection, which will ſecure it indubitably from the malevolent cenſures of any ignorant, arrogant, or malignant perſon whatſoever. If in the intervals of your high contemplations your ſerious thoughts shall deſcend to divert them a little, as before, ſo now after the Dedication and Impreſſion,
in reading thoſe Sceanes, I muſt ever eſteem it an unparalel'd honour to me, who am,

closer.signed: Your Majeſties moſt humble, moſt obedient, and moſt faithfull Servant William Lower

div.head: PROLOGUE.
div.l: BEfore I enter'd, I vvas tould vvhat novv
I ſee decypher'd upon every brovv;
A ſullen ſadnes, and cloſe murmurs ſay,
"The Title is enough to damn the Play
"The Bill condemns before the Action, Pox
"Vpon the Poet vvith his Paradox,
"Noble Ingratitude, o barbarous ſound!
"Vertue vvill die to ſee that Monſter crovvn'd:
Strange voices theſe, ſtrange cenſures from the vvits,
For ſuch he take you, every one that ſits
Sp • ctat • ur here uſurps a priviledge,
VVhich is unjuſt, before he hears, to judge,
VViſe, and juſt Iuries, vvho in every cauſe
Strictly obſerve the cuſtom of the Lavvs,
The bottome ſound, and ne'r their verdicts bring
Vpon the ſuperficies of a thing;
They vveigh the ground of matters vvell, and ne'r
Proceed to ſentence till they ſee all cleer;
Have patience then a little, and ſuſpend
Your judgments till you ſee us at the end
Of the fifth Act; three hours vvill ſoon be paſs'd,
In Sceans and Songs the minutes fly too faſt;
Then if vve do'nt maintain our Paradox,
Let me be sham'd, and ſit three hours i' th' ſtocks
For punishing your patience; if the crime
Deſerves more rigour, let a longer time
Of penance be preſcrib'd me there; but I
Hope from your judgments, juſtice, clemency,
A nobler ſentence, and that you'll allovv
Me next a Lavvrell vvreath to crovvn my brovv.

div.head: ACTORS.

list.item: ZELINDA, Daughter to Lindarache, diſguiſed like a man under the name of Ormin, in the habit of a Slave.
ZEGRY, Maſter to Zelinda, and Lover of Fatima.
FATIMA, Miſtreſſe to Zegry, and in Love with Adibar.
ABENCERAGE, under the name of Almanſor, Brother to Zelinda.
LINDARACHE, Mother to Zelinda, and to Abencerage.

div.stage: The Scene is in the Forreſt of Argier.

div.head: ACT. I.
SCENE I, ORMIN alone.
div.l: CHarming aboad, delightfull ſolitude,
Fair places where I firſt receiv'd my life
And love, old trees, cleer brooks, whoſe ſhade and murmur
Speak pity for my ſorrowfull adventure,
Sweet Zephirs, Eccho, nocks, and ſilent forreſts,
Be witneſſes all of my ſecret griefs:
I am no more now that Zelinda ſometime
Adored by the worthieſt Lovers of
The country round about; alas! I ſerve
Vnder the habit of a Slave, a traitor
With an unparraleld'd fidelity,
Traitor in Love, I meane, not otherwiſe,
A Hero, but ingratefull, one who ſlatters me
In my extream misfortune, yet would hate me,
If he knew that I Love him. Gentle trees,
Happy are you, although the rigourous Winter
Vſeth you hardly, for when the fair Spring
Maketh the cold to ceaſe, you ſuddenly
Reſume your anciet verdure, and at harveſt,
Vpon your branches wee ſee fruits, where formerly
Hung Iſicles: my fortune's not ſo good;
Each of the ſeaſons have 'twice chaung'd, ſince Love
Reſolved to afflict me, all which time
I've languished continually, and could not
Pretend to the repoſe my heart hath loſt:
He whom I love with ſo much conſtancy
Is falſe and fleeting; o Gods! here he comet.

sp.speaker: ZEGRY.
sp.p: Know that to morrow we will depart hence.

sp.speaker: ORMIN.
sp.l: What! will you leave ſo ſoon your native country,
Theſe cottages, theſe woods and theſe fair meadows?

sp.speaker: ZEGRY.
sp.l: I have not hid from thee that in thoſe places
I love the ſweet Fatima, a rich Maſter-peice
Of Heaven, and hop'd to ſee that Beauty here
So cherish'd and ador'd; but I have learn'd
That she is now at Tunis with her Father;
And though this happy reſidence may be ſaid
To be a ſecond Paradiſe, I cannot
See any fair thing here, ſince she is abſent.

sp.speaker: ORMIN.
sp.l: How happy is Fatima, and how miſerable
Am I! — aſide.

sp.speaker: ZEGRY.
sp.l: How grievous is her abſence to
My amourous ſoul! to render me by her,
To morrow by the break of day we'll take
Our way for Tunis, I shall be too happy,
If I may ſee her, and I do believe
That she will bear ſome part too in my joy;
She had no little trouble, I perceiv'd,
For my departure laſt, and without doubt
I'm not indifferent to her.

sp.speaker: ORMIN.
sp.l: Certainly
Her flame will not be quench'd.

sp.speaker: ORMIN.
sp.p: And that is all my feare — aſide.

sp.speaker: ALABEZ.
sp.l: Cheer up, cheer up,
Smother your ſighs, I have a counter poiſon
For all your ſorrows.

sp.speaker: ZEGRY.
sp.l: Speak it then without
Holding us long in trouble.

sp.speaker: ALABEZ.
sp.l: Give me leave.
Firſt, if you pleaſe, to take a little breath.

sp.speaker: ZEGRY.
sp.l: Oh thou mak'ſt me.
Suffer too much? tell it unto us quickly.

sp.speaker: ZEGRY.
sp.l: Is't then ſome misfortune
Sent me by deſtiny?

sp.speaker: ALABEZ.
sp.l: I ſay agiane.
You might die with it, but t'would be with joy;
Fatima yeſterday late in the evening
Arrived in theſe quarters.

sp.speaker: ZEGRY.
sp.l: Is it poſſible,
Fatima?

sp.speaker: ALABEZ.
sp.p: Yes, aſſure you, I have ſeen her.

sp.speaker: ALABEZ.
sp.l: I am no aſſe.
I did obſerve her well, and knew her perfectly.
Her Slave, who was my Miſtreſſe formerly,
Entered juſt now with her into that wood.

sp.speaker: ZEGRY.
sp.p: Good Gods? do I not ſee her?

sp.speaker: ALABEZ.
sp.l: Yes, that's she
Which paſſeth by.

sp.speaker: ZEGRY.
sp.l: What luſtre hath her eye,
What grace her gate?

sp.speaker: ZEGRY.
sp.p: I ſee a thouſand new charms there.

sp.speaker: ALABEZ.
sp.p: Are you beſotted? wil you not ſalute her?

sp.speaker: ZEGRY.
sp.l: No, to perform that complement, I'le give her
A viſit, when I shall have without doubt
My ſoul leſſe in diſorder.

sp.speaker: ALABEZ.
sp.l:
For m •
part,
Who do not love ſo daintily, I will,
Without deferring it, make my addreſſe.

sp.speaker: ZEGRY.
sp.l: Without diſcovering our ſelves, we may
From hence know by the uſage of the ſervant,
In what eſteem the Maſter is at preſent.

sp.speaker: ALABEZ.
sp.p: SWeet Beauties welcome, from what quarters come you?

sp.speaker: CHARIFA.
sp.p: What means this inſolent? Go on your way

sp.speaker: ALABEZ.
sp.l: How's this? inſtead of kiſſes and embraces,
As I expected, I am quarrel▪d with:
Charifa, whence this change?

sp.speaker: FATIMA.
sp.l: What's that follow
Which followes us?

sp.speaker: CHARIFA.
sp.l: Tis an impertinent,
Whom I know not.

sp.speaker: ALABEZ.
sp.l: I am much changed then
Since this laſt voyage; but thy ſoul is chag'd
And not my viſage, without doubt thy Miſtreſſe
Hath better eyes, and more wit; she will know
An old, and a familiar acquaintance.

sp.speaker: ALABEZ.
sp.l: Should you not know him neither?
Is his name raz'd out of your memory?

sp.speaker: ALABEZ.
sp.l: How, Madam, is it poſſible you can
Forget the valiant Zegry?

sp.speaker: ZEGRY.
sp.l: Heaven?
What ſtrange inconſtancy is this? who ever
Could have imagin'd it? — aſide.

sp.speaker: ALABEZ.
sp.l: That noble and illuſtrious ſucceſſour
Of thoſe brave warriers who even in Spain
Have gathered Lawrells, and brought home faire ſpoils,
Madam, your faithfull Lover, Zaida's brother.

sp.speaker: ALABEZ.
sp.p: You ask not how he doth.

sp.speaker: FATIMA.
sp.l: What intereſt
Have I in his ſweet perſon? happily
He's dead.

sp.speaker: FATIMA.
sp.l: We are all mortall;
The Prophet hath his ſoul.

sp.speaker: CHARIFA.
sp.l: A faithfull ſervant
Would have accompanied his Maſter; why
Art thou not dead too?

sp.speaker: ALABEZ.
sp.l: Only to enrage thee.
Zegry diſcovering himſelf.

sp.speaker: ZEGRY.
sp.l: The Prophet hath his ſoul, o falſe Fatima!
Is't thus you do expreſſe your goodneſs to me?
Deceitfull object, my return, I ſee,
Diſpleaſeth you, who would deſpiſe me dead,
Muſt hate me living, I diſturb with pleaſure
That faithleſs joy which the delightfull news
Of my feign'd death procur'd you: I live ſtill
Ingratefull, but I live no more for you:
My paſſion is transform'd all into fury:
As much as I lov'd you, I now deſpiſe you:
My heart shakes of ſo rigourous a yoak:
Love raiſeth no more ſighs, nor fires within me,
Only I ſigh that I us'd ſo much care
To pleaſe you, and if I burn yet, it is
With anger, not with love.

sp.speaker: ORMIN.
sp.l: Oh this ſucceſſe
Anſwereth my wishes fully? — aſide.

sp.speaker: FATIMA.
sp.l: This confeſſion
Surpriſeth, but no way afflicteth me;
My firſt diſcourſe should make you underſtand
That I'm not very tender hearted to you,
And, me thinks, after ſuch a cleer contempt
As was expreſſed there you might believe
Nothing should trouble me that comes from you,
Vnleſſ your amourous addreſſe: I have
A thouſand other Lovers braver far
Then you, and therefore I daign not to put you
In the rank of my conqueſts.

sp.speaker: ZEGRY.
sp.l: Sure, your pride
Is greater then your beauty, the charm is
Diſſolv'd wherein I formerly was held;
Tis true, I ſometime thought you beautifull;
But I was amourous, and therefore not
To be believed, having now my ſpirit
No more diſordered, you ceaſe to be fair
And I to be abuſed, whereas you
Pleaſed me formerly, it was becauſe
It is impoſſible for me, when I
Am lov'd, to be inſenſible.

sp.speaker: FATIMA.
sp.l: I love you?
Heaven! what a ſtrange opinion is this?
I never had but ſtrong averſion for you.
All your indeavours ſerv'd but to diſpleaſe me;
But though I hated you, I lov'd your Siſter,
And t▪ was for her ſake that I feign'd to have
Some pitty for your paſſions; her prayer
A hundred times reſtain'd my hate, you ſware
That your daies did depend upon my ſight,
And yeelding unto her deſites I did
Enforce mine eyes to ſmile, when my heart frown'd,
To the end not to be cauſe of your death.

sp.speaker: ZEGRY.
sp.p: Your eyes have never made a mortall wound.

sp.speaker: FATIMA.
sp.l: Take heed that your do not revive again,
One Only of my looks darted more gently,
Can change this violent anger into love;
But I am verie nice of ſuch a look,
It is too rich a price, Sir, for your conqueſt
I limit my deſires to ſee you never,
Adieu, become wiſe, and leave me in peace.

sp.speaker: ZEGRY.
sp.l: YEs falſe Fatima, I will become wiſe,
Thy contempt is unjuſt, but mine is lawfull:
Since thou pretendeſt but to make thee hated,
I will obey thee, thy unworthy trophy,
My heart shal be no more, his charmes are broken,
His flames are quench'd; Alabez, follow her
Cloſe at the heels, even unto her houſe;
But have a care not to diſcover thee.

sp.speaker: ORMIN.
sp.l: Her pride's unjuſt, and not to be endur'd;
Your change herein is but too equitable,
O how wel should you do to free your heart
From the imperious captivity
Of ſuch a cruel conquerour, you are
Born with too many fair advantages,
To obtain nothing but eternall wrongs;
There are Sir, other beauties in the world
VVhich would be glad to share their flame with yours,
To imitate your ſighs, and which would tell you
That the reſplendent honour of a crown
Is beneath that to be beloved of
An object that one loves Contempt in love
Deſerves to be repayed with contempt,
And who refuſeth, is not worthy of,
For the moſt part, the perſon that's refuſ'd.

sp.speaker: ZEGRY.
sp.l: How great my griefs are, and how grievous is
This proud contempt? o light, and wavering Sex!
O black ingratitude! ſince love began
To trouble Lovers, was there ever torment
Equall to mine? I feel my heart infected
VVith all imaginary griefs.

sp.speaker: ORMIN,
sp.l: Oh? Sir,
Believe me, I know ſome that are much more
To be lamented, and if what I know
VVere reveald to you, you should have great cauſe
Of comfort by it.

sp.speaker: ZEGRY.
sp.l: Oh ſpeak, and divert
The grief which doth oppreſſe me. oftentimes
A wretch is pleaſed in his miſery
VVhen he ſees that he ſuffers not alone.

sp.speaker: ORMIN.
sp.l: O love, I pray thee make his heart grow tender
At the recitall of the evill which he
Hath cauſed me, oh make him Senſible
Of my ſad ſufferings? — a ſide.
A young Beauty, Sir,
VVhoſe name and birth, if you pleaſe I'l conceal
Through decency, only thus much I'l tell you,
That she was neer to me and lov'd me deerly,
Scarce yet attained to the fifteenth yeer,
When love and marriage was propoſed to her,
And she commanded to expect for huſband
A man too lovely, and to much belov'd;
And who for his part was ſo farre from being
Warm'd with a mutuall flame, that he unlawfully
Took an affection for another object:
His faithfull Lover with grief underſtood it
But yet a worſe misfortune afterward
Surpriſed her, th' ingratefull brak th' accord
Of the approaching marriage, and departed
For a long voyage without ſeeing her;
I can aſſure you that her grief was quick,
And anger ardent after this affront;
But yet her anger was leſſe then her love:
Although, th' inconſtant left her, she retain'd him
Still in her ſoul, and valuing not her ſex,
Nor fearing death, i▪ th' habit of a man
She followed his ſteps.

sp.speaker: ZEGRY.
sp.l: O barbarous rigour!
O lamentable paſſion!

sp.speaker: ORMIN.
sp.l: You wil be
More touch'd when you shall know the reſt: ſcarce was she
Embarked on the ſea, when by a new,
And worſe misfortune certain infamous rovers
Surpriſ'd her veſſel, and not long time after
They ſould her unto that ingratefull man,
Who falſly and unworthly forſook her:
And ſo at laſt it hapened that Fortune
Aſwell as Love would put her into chains:
But she ſtill without changing heart, or habit,
Found ſweetnes in this double ſlavery;
Far from deſiring to be free, she follow'd
Her faithles friend into his native country,
And fearing not to be diſcovered,
Serv'd this deceitfull Maſter without hope,
Indeavoured to pleaſe him, and therein
Proſper'd ſo well, that he eſteem'd her zeal,
And conceal'd nothing from her; but this kindnes
Was not a cure, but corſive to her grief,
Becauſe it made her privy to the happines
Her Rivall did enjoy in the affection
Of him she lov'd, who every day proteſted
Vnto her, that rather then loſe her love,
He'd loſe his life.

sp.speaker: ZEGRY.
sp.l: Vnparalel'd punishment!
Cruell injuſtice!

sp.speaker: ORMIN.
sp.l: Gods! he groweth tender,
Love be propitious to me, — aſide.
Sir, what ſay you,
Is not ſhe more then you to be lamented?
Compared to her torments, your afflictions
Are ſweet. You anſwer not.

sp.speaker: ZEGRY.
sp.l: Yes, yes, I grant it
I ought to hate her, but I've too much weaknes:
Oh fair Fatima!

sp.speaker: ORMIN.
sp.l: You anſwer nothing
To what I ſaid.

sp.speaker: ZEGRY.
sp.p: What ſpak'ſt thou to me of?

sp.speaker: ORMIN.
sp.l: Of a young maid
Oppreſs'd and injured in love.

sp.speaker: ZEGRY.
sp.l: My thoughts
Were otherwiſe imploy'd, and troubled,
I heard thee not, at leaſt I have forgotten.

sp.speaker: ORMIN.
sp.l: You ſeemed to compaſſionate her grief,
And her misfortune very much.

sp.speaker: ZEGRY,
sp.l: Alas!
I onely thought upon my proper grief.

sp.speaker: ORMIN,
sp.l: What! shall th' ingratefull and cruel Fatima
Although she quits your heart thus, have the glory
To live ſtill in your memory? oh no,
Banish her thence; but if you'l think of her,
To eaſe your evills a little, imploy your thought
Onely to think of her defects; remember
That she's too proud, and fancy to your ſelf
That she's not fair enough, to hould ſo noble
And ſuch a faithfull Lover as you are,
That there is nothing charming in her eyes,
Nor in her cheeks, that her proportion,
Her poſture, ſtature, gate, and carriage
Have nothing commendable, that her witt —

sp.speaker: ZEGRY
sp.l: Ormin, no more, I cannot ſuffer yet
She should be injur'd; that ingrateful Beauty,
Who laughs with ſcorn at my ſad languishment,
Hath no defect at all but her fierce rigour;
And I fear that in ſpight of this defect,
My violent love will triumph o'r mine anger.

sp.speaker: ORMIN.
sp.l: What, shall Fatima be ſo proud, and you
So humble? shall she be compoſ'd of Ice,
And you of fire? muſt you perſiſt to love her,
When she deſpiſeth you? oh fall no more
Into that fatall errour. It belongs, Sir
But to low ſpirits to ſuffer without hate,
Such a contempt; to leave what flyeth us,
Is little trouble, and when hope is quench'd,
Love should be querched alſo.

sp.speaker: ZEGRI.
sp.l: What thou ſayſt,
Ormin, is verie true, I should indeed
Follow Fatima in her lightnes to me,
I should in her unkindnes trace her ſteps,
I should be as inſenſible as she's
Severe and rigourous, my flam'es an errour,
I doe confeſſe it, but I love this errour,
Thy faithfull counſels are not ſeaſonable,
Love hath not yet given place unto my reaſon,
I'm born to languish, and to die for her;
Although she be ingratefull she is not
The leſſe faire for it.

sp.speaker: ORMIN.
sp.l: The falſe hope that flatter'd me
Fled in a moment; miſerable Lover,
And too unjuſt! — a ſide

sp.speaker: ALMANSOR.
sp.l: FRiend, I am very joyfull
To meet thee.

sp.speaker: ZEGRY.
sp.l: My content is ſtill compleat,
When I behold thy face, as in thy abſence,
Nothing ſeems ſweet unto me: Now I ſee
Th'art habited like us, this garment is
Well made.

sp.speaker: ALMANSOR.
sp.l: I took it juſt now in th'apartment
I have in thy abode.

sp.speaker: ZEGRY.
sp.l: This Shepheards habit
Becomes thee rarely; but for an Almanſor,
It is too much abaſement.

sp.speaker: ALMANSOR.
sp.l: Sure the habit
Takes nothing from the luſtre of the merit,
In imitating thee, I cannot erre;
Thee, whoſe heart is as noble as thy race,
And unto whoſe aid in an eminent danger
I owe my life.

sp.speaker: ZEGRY.
sp.l: The Shepheards of this wood
And fair Campania, are deſcended from
Thoſe Heros, who in time paſs'd conquer'd Spain
From thoſe renowned Moors, whoſe great exploits
Made the Kings of a hundred Chriſtian people
Tremble for fear, and who ſeeing Tunis conquer'd
By Charls the fifth, conſerve here in theſe places
Their glory and their freedom, ſecretly
Diſpoſe the hearts of the moſt Zealous Kings
To drive the Chriſtias frō this deſolate coūtry,
And are in readines to joyn themſelves,
And to encreaſe the firſt fair levies which
Shall be imploy'd on ſuch an expedition.

sp.speaker: ALMANSOR.
sp.l: I know that this fair deſert's like a Court:
But haſt thou heard yet that Gomella is
Return'd heer? ſuffer me at preſent, Zegry,
To leave thee, he is my familiar friend,
And I owe him a viſit.

sp.speaker: ZEGRY.
sp.l: Then thou know'ſt

sp.speaker: ALMANSOR.
sp.l: Yes, that Beauty hath receiv'd
The light from brave Gomella; friend adiew,
I will return to thee with ſpeed, excuſe me
At preſent, I muſt ſpeak with him upon
A buſines of importance. — Exit Almanſor.

sp.speaker: ZEGRY.
sp.l: A buſines of importance? oh that word
Redoubleth my affliction; to marry
Fatima, without doubt, is his deſign:
Oh Heave? haſt thou ordain'd that, to make up
The full proportion of my miſery,
My deareſt friēd should rob me of my Miſtreſſe?
Alas! if this be true, grief, fure will kill me;
Dear Ormin, let us uſe our beſt indeavour
To hinder this misfortune; I expect
My only remedy from thy adviſe.
The moſt reſplendent wit yeildeth to thine
In point of knowledge, I have obſerv'd in thee
Something thats great, and extraordinary;
Thy judgment charms me, and thy care ſurpriſeth me.

sp.speaker: ORMIN.
sp.p: Sir, I'm your Slave, and glory to be ſo.

sp.speaker: ZEGRY.
sp.l: No, no, I make thee free, henceforth be thou
Thy Maſters friend.

sp.speaker: ORMIN.
sp.l: The ſweeteſt liberty
Pleaſeth my fancy leſſe then the chains which
I bear for you.

sp.speaker: ZEGRY
sp.l: This zeal ſo little common,
Makes me grow tender, and amazeth me.
Quit, quit thy fetters, Ormin, I commmand it,
Be free.

sp.speaker: ORMIN
sp.l: Since tis your pleaſure, I obey;
Alas! what have I ſaid, Love, can I be
At liberty, when my heart is not free?

div.trailer: The end of the first Act.

div.head: ACT II.

sp.speaker: FATIMA.
sp.l: ENter again, ſweet Zaida, ceremony
Between us should be banish'd, wherefore will you
Trouble your ſelf unneceſſarily?

sp.speaker: ZAIDA.
sp.p: Since you will have it ſo, I'l go no further.

sp.speaker: FATIMA.
sp.l: I may aſſure my ſelf then ere we part,
That Adibar shall have no free admittance
To your ſociety, I have already
Told you, that formerly he loved me;
But now I know that you give laws to him
And I have cauſe to hope that, if you ſcorn him,
He may return unto his firſt ſubjection.

sp.speaker: ZAIDA.
sp.l: Fatima, be aſſur'd that he shall be
Repuls'd, his love will be but troubleſome;
But if you love me, forget not to feign
Some kindnes for my brother; I beſeech you
For my ſake give him cauſe to hope a little.

sp.speaker: FATIMA.
sp.l: Adieu, I promiſe you that at next meeting
I will receive him better. — Exit Fatima.

sp.speaker: ZAIDA.
sp.l: WHat think'ſt thou
Of fair Fatima, and of her requeſt?

sp.speaker: MEDINA.
sp.l: I think that Adibar is not a perſon
To be deſpis'd.

sp.speaker: ZAIDA.
sp.l: True, but I am too proud
T'accept a heart that hath been conquered
By any other, and would now be mine
Trough an inconſtancie, but if I durſt
To love —

sp.speaker: ZAIDA.
sp.l: Oh Medina!
I muſt not ſpeak the reſt.

sp.speaker: MEDINA.
sp.l: But I divine it;
You are in love, and I have cauſe to judge
That it is with Almanſor, that fair ſtranger

sp.speaker: ZAIDA.
sp.p: Who, I in love with him?

sp.speaker: MEDINA.
sp.l: Why not, I pray you,
Is that a crime?

sp.speaker: ZAIDA.
sp.l: Oh do not name that love,
Which is no other but a fair eſteem.

sp.speaker: MEDINA.
sp.l: There is ſo little difference between
Eſteem and love, that often times we take then
One for the other, and are ſo deceiv'd.

sp.speaker: ZAIDA.
sp.l: I cannot but remember that my brother
In his laſt voyage did conclude my marriage
In Argier, that he who's deſign'd to be
My husband, is heer shortly to arrive,
And that my heart ought to reſerve it ſelf
Wholy for him. Beſides in thy opinion.
Would it not argue a great weaknes in me
To love this ſtranger, though my brothers friend.
Who hath not been above a moneth among u •
And whoſe deſert as yet's unknown unto me

sp.speaker: MEDINA.
sp.l: Seeing this Stranger, who's not of the vulgate,
Deſerves to be careſſed of your brother,
There's reaſon to believe that he deſerves
To be your Lover, and I can't conceive
Why your mouth will conceal the flame which is
So cleerly for him in your eyes and countenance.
As often as he commeth with your brother
To viſit you, your looks ſeem to be fix'd
Wholy one him, and at the ſame time alſo
I obſerv'd often that the ſtranger ey'd you
With the ſame ardour.

sp.speaker: ZAIDA.
sp.l: Prethee, ſpeak in earneſt,
Did'ſt ſee him to behold me oftentimes?

sp.speaker: MEDINA.
sp.l: You ask it me with very much impreſſement:
I do believe in leſſe time then an howr,
That you have queſtion'd me upon this point
More then a hundred times; your curioſity
Gives me a full aſſurance that his looks
Displeaſe you not, nor wound your modeſty

sp.speaker: ZAIDA.
sp.l: Alas! can one in juſtice be offended,
To be belov'd?

sp.speaker: MEDINA.
sp.l: If his love pleaſeth you, I think his perſon
Will pleaſe you equally.

sp.speaker: ZAIDA.
sp.l: I conſider him
Without interpreter; but perhaps, he loves
Elſewhere, and I may be unpleaſing to him.

sp.speaker: MEDINA.
sp.l: Madam, although you fain would cover it,
This fond ſuſpition publisheth your flame,
Iealouſy alwaies is daughter of love.

sp.speaker: ZAIDA.
sp.l: vvould it pleaſ'd Heaven, that he were free, and that
He thought me fair, But I ſee him come forth
Gomella's houſe, I'l ſatisfy my ſelf
In ſounding of his ſoul, upon this bank
I will repoſe my ſelf, and feign to ſleep.

sp.speaker: MEDINA.
sp.p: VVhat's your deſign? I cannot comprehend it.

sp.speaker: ZAIDA.
sp.p: VVithdraw, anon thou't underſtand it better.

div.head: SCENE III.

sp.speaker: ALMANSOR.
sp.l: Gomella is expecting his return.
In viſit, heer I may conveniently
Dream of my new love: Heaven! do I not ſee
Vnder that flourishing shade the beautious ſubject
Of my ſad ſufferings? Love in this encounter
Seemeth to flatter me ſufficiently;
It is the lovely Zaida without doubt:
How ſweetly, and with what tranquility
Doth that fair one repoſe, whil'ſt wretched I
Languish with the diſeaſe which she procures me?
Surely she cannot hear me now, I may
Speak at this preſent unto her of love,
And not offend her; but alas! the rigour
Of my ſad deſtiny is great, when I
Preſume to ſpeak, I fear that she may hear me.
You that have taught me the true uſe of ſighs,
Dear object of my joy and of my griefs;
Suffer my amorous and ſilent ſoul.
T▪ expreſſe its ſecret paſſion before you,
And to complain heer of a thouſand evills
Which you have made me ſuffer, yet unkrown
Vnto your ſelf: and you reſplendent ſources
Of all my fires, from whence I have deriv'd
Such violent heats, fair charming eyes, the authors
Of my captivity, enjoy the reſt,
Which your have taken from me: If I ſee
The poppies which shut up your lids, be not
Offended that you loſe your lights, the Sun
Is ſubject to the ſame eclipſe, and can
No more then you, diſpenſe himſelf thereof.

div.stage: Zaida feigning her ſelf in a dream.

sp.speaker: ZAIDA.
sp.l: Oh! rigourous torment!
To burn, to languish, and not dare to ſpeak it,
Alas!

sp.speaker: ZAIDA
sp.l: We reſent
One and the ſame heat.

sp.speaker: ZAIDA.
sp.l: Cruel conſtraints!
When shal we be content, when shal our plaints
Have end?

sp.speaker: ALMANSOR.
sp.l: In this great extaſie of joy,
All my reſpects are vain; to give her thanks.
I'l kiſſe her fair hands. — He kiſſeth her hands.

sp.speaker: ZAIDA.
sp.p:
Hold, inſolent; whence doth proceed this boldnes? —
feigning to awake,

sp.speaker: ALMANSOR.
sp.l: What have I done? — aſide.
I came to give you thanks.

sp.speaker: ZAIDA.
sp.l: Now, I know not:
I'm ſure I never gave you any matter
For this acknowledgment, who ever will
Conſult th' apparence of the thing, shal find
That I have much indifference for you;
But though I had leſſe, was it fit to trouble
My reſt, in making your acknowledgement?

sp.speaker: ALMANZOR.
sp.l: Excuſe my tranſport, beautious Shepheardeſſe,
If I had leſſe lov'd, I had been leſſe guilty;
In this occaſion a Wary Lover
Would have expreſſed little love in shewing
Too much reſpect; and whatſoer my crime be,
It would be pardoned, if you ſlept ſtil;
But, alas! my good fortune is ſoon chang'd,
I find that you awake but to afflict me,
Your eyes in taking unto them again
Their grace and luſtre, take unto them alſo
At the ſame time their uſual cruelty.
And that moſt charming hope which I ſo little
Enjoyed, vanish'd with your ſleep.

sp.speaker: ZAIDA.
sp.l: This is
An ill expreſſion of your ſelf, that word
Of hope gives me aſtonishment, I never
Gave it, nor took it yet from any perſon.

sp.speaker: ALMANZOR.
sp.l: If I might dare to credit your diſcourſe,
At leaſt you had not an averſion for me,
Nothing would be equall to my good fortune,
You would not find my preſence trouble ſome,
I should be uſed better, I should be
Eſteem'd and poſſibly—

sp.speaker: ALMANZOR.
sp.l: I might be
Belov'd.

sp.speaker: ZAIDA.
sp.l: Belov'd! of whom; if you magine
Of me, you are miſtaken.

sp.speaker: ALMAZOR.
sp.l: Notwithſtanding
You honored me ſo much to tell me ſo:
If I may but believe your voice, I have
Place in your heart, you are my witneſſe and
My judge both at one time; oh diſavow not
That favorable ſentence, that fair Oracle
Proceding from an adorable mouth,
Thoſe words ſo full of charms pronounc'd in ſleep,
Which promiſed me bleſſings ſoſoon vanish'd

sp.speaker: ZAIDA.
sp.l: I dreamt, Almanſor, and you are not ignorant
That a dream oftentimes is a deceiver,
And ſtil a lie.

sp.speaker: ALMANSOR.
sp.l: True, a dream is my glory;
But I have paſſions which are real truths,
The flame with in mine eyes hath appear'd to you
Too cleer, to be concealed, and the coldnes
Which you expreſſe unto me, quencheth not
My love, altbough it ruineth my hope.

sp.speaker: ZAIDA.
sp.l: This love comes very late, and really
I'm troubled at it, you know wel that I
Am otherwiſe engag'd.

sp.speaker: ALMANSOR.
sp.l: Alas! I cannot
Deny but I have heard ſay that a Lover
Favoured of Heaven is to come shortly heer
To take you from mine eyes, I know you love him
Before you ſee him, therefore I'le not trouble
Your pleaſures, nor his joy: how great ſoever
His happines be, I do intend to ſuffer it
VVithout complaining of you, but withall
I doe intend to die. As ſoon as you
Shall depart hence upon the fatal voyage
Ordained, where your happy mariage
Muſt be accomplish'd, Know, at the ſame time,
That you shall ſee me in my griefs exceſſe
Depart to go unto the grave, where thoſe
Remains of fire which ſparkle in my boſom,
Atter my death shall ſtill yet warm my ashes.
ZAID; Fortune doth ow you, Sir, a happier lot
ALM: My good or evill lot depends on you.
All other favours would be troubleſome:
Laſtly I do adore you, and not fortune.

sp.speaker: ZAIDA.
sp.l: What expect you from me in the condition
Wherein I am?

sp.speaker: ALMANSOR.
sp.l: Immortall heats and torments;
I ſtill muſt love without hope to be loved.

sp.speaker: ZAIDA.
sp.p: Who loves much, may hope to be loved likewiſe.

sp.speaker: ALMANSOR.
sp.p: What may I hope one day for better uſage?

sp.speaker: ZAIDA.
sp.l: Conſult with your fidelity upon it.
ALM: Your ſoul appeareth too inſenſible
To love.
ZAID: A conſtant Lover may do much;
The firſt refuſal ought not to aſtonish
Any one that hath love enough to give it.

sp.speaker: ALMANSOR.
sp.p: Oh this is plain enough to my glad ſenſe!

sp.speaker: ZAIDA.
sp.l: The blood ſtrikes up unto my brow; alas!
I've ſaid too much, and now I blush for shame on't.
ALM: This glorious confeſſion rendereth me
Too happy and content.
ZAID: Dreams ſometimes are not
VVithout effect; but the Sun hath already
Finished his career, let us go in
Yet further to diſcourſe upon this matter
I fear that troubleſome.

sp.speaker: ADIBAR.
sp.l: Without too much ambition may I hope
The honour to take you by the fair hand
The one is free, may I preſume to kiſſe it?

sp.speaker: ZAIDA.
sp.p: I have no need, Sir, of your ſervices.

sp.speaker: ADIBAR.
sp.l: They may be worth a Strangers, notwithſtanding
Your ſcorn of me.

sp.speaker: ZAIDA.
sp.l: In thinking to oblige me,
You may diſpleaſe me, by this odd expreſſion.

sp.speaker: ADIBAR.
sp.l: The Prophet, who knows how I reverence you,
Knows alſo how far forth I fear your anger,
And the cares which I take, should well aſſure you,
That I come heer but for to honour you:
May I aſide declare a ſecret to you?
Of ſome importance?

sp.speaker: ZAIDA.
sp.l: Nothing is ſo important
As decency, which in th' opinion
Of every one, allowes we not the Liberty
To hear the ſecrets of ſuch as you are.

sp.speaker: ADIBAR.
sp.l: I deſire nothing of you what another
Doth not obtain.

sp.speaker: ZAIDA.
sp.l: His diſcourſe pleaſeth me,
And yours I hate.

sp.speaker: ALMANSOR.
sp.l: You take an unfit time
To tell your ſecrets, to the indiſcreet
Love ſeldome is propitious; th' incivility
Which your pride doth expreſſe, is an ill meās
To gain eſteem.

sp.speaker: ADIBAR.
sp.l: I am not heer to take
Leſſons from you.

sp.speaker: ALMANSOR.
sp.l: I give them to your equals
To all intents and purpoſes.

sp.speaker: ADIBAR.
sp.l: This paſſion.
Which carries you away, convicteth you,
And doth excuſe me of the incivility
Wherewith your errour charge me; a man
Better inſtructed, to avoid ſuſpition,
Would have retir'd himſelf out of reſpect;
You are too groſſe; but as you are a Stranger,
I ought to bear a little with your ignorance.

sp.speaker: ZAIDA.
sp.l: You have the faults which you cōdemn in him;
This Stranger doth oblige me, and you trouble me.

sp.speaker: ADIBAR.
sp.p: Yet you should take away your hand from him — to Zaida.

sp.speaker: ALMANSOR.
sp.p: If she should do it, you would be in danger.

sp.speaker: ADIBAR.
sp.p: In quitting her, you might run to your death.

sp.speaker: ALMNASOR.
sp.p: I reſpect Zaida, you I do deſpiſe.

sp.speaker: ADIBAR.
sp.l: If by the ſame reſpect I were not ſtop'd,
In my revenge, your punishment should ſoon
Follow your inſolence.

sp.speaker: ZAIDA.
sp.l: Theſe haſty motions
Are ſorry paſſtimes for me; by this violence
I know that neither of you doth reſpect me,
But both offend me.

sp.speaker: ALMMANSOR.
sp.l: Do you take
Your hand from me to anſwer his deſires?
My Rivall will become too proud at this:
Should you affrōt me wit deſign to pleaſe him?

sp.speaker: ZAIDA.
sp.l: By what right alſo am I bound to give
You ſatisfaction?

sp.speaker: ADIBAR.
sp.l: Madam, I beſeech you,
Vſe no conſtraint to your free inclination
In my behalf, I know which of us two
Pleaſeth you beſt, I yeild to him in fortune,
And perhaps too in merit, his diſcourſe
Is acceptable, mine is hatefull to you;
Of this truth I cannot be ignorant;
Therefore to th' end I may not trouble you,
I will retire me, my reſpect for you
Is ſtronger then the jealouſie, wherewith
My amourous ſoul is juſtly ſeiſed now,
And I will force all my reſentiments for you,
Yea evē to hate my ſelf, if you should hate me.
Let here my happy Rivall without trouble
Diſcourſe with you, eſtablish, if you pleaſe,
His happines at the expenſe of mine;
But take this into your conſideration
That Adibar, who quits you with regret,
Though the leaſt lov'd, is not the leaſt diſcreet.

sp.speaker: ZAIDA.
sp.p: VVhere go you Adibar? come back again.

sp.speaker: ZAIDA.
sp.l: No, once more
I ſay come back again; if you eſteem me,
You will return, to take away ſuſpitions
Oppoſed to my glory, lend me, pray you,
Your hand, and lead me back. — he gives her his hand.

sp.speaker: ALMANSOR.
sp.l: Oh! I cannot
Suffer this cruell injury.

sp.speaker: ZAIDA.
sp.l: Stay I command you, on pain of my hate.

sp.speaker: ALMANZOR.
sp.p: Hear me a word or two,

sp.speaker: ZAIDA.
sp.l: I can't be mov'd.
Reaſon I hear, and duty is my guide.

sp.speaker: ALMANZOR.
sp.l:
What unexpected cl ••
〈◊〉 thunder's this,
Which ruineth my joy thus with my hope?

l.hi: Reaſon I hear, and duty is my guide;

sp.l: My conſtancy, at theſe words giveth place
To my deſpair; and duty is my guide
No, cruell Zaida in following Adibar,
Tis Love that guides you: but what! I may be
Too rash in cenſuring her ſo; perhaps
She doth enforce herſelf in quitting me,
And doth prefer my Rivall here before me,
To take off all ſuſpition of our love.
She loves, she loves me; oh! what ſay I, fool?
without doubt she hath left me through contempt.
Love, like to fickle Fortune is inconſtant,
His Empire, doth reſemble his who doth
Command the ſea, where nothing is ſecure,
To day a calm, to morrow a ſad ſtorm,
And every minute, the moſt fortunate
Vpon that element, may fear a change.
Even in the Port, We often ſuffer Shipwrack:
Theſe are ſad truths, whereof I need not doubt:
But what maketh my Slave ſo haſtily
T'addreſſe his ſteps unto me?

sp.speaker: ALMANZOR.
sp.l: Haſt thou found

sp.speaker: GAZVL.
sp.l: Yes, Sir. and I think that he

Advāceth heer with large ſteps to embrace yo •
▪

sp.speaker: ALMANSOR.
sp.p: Tis that which my care should prevent.

sp.speaker: GAZVL.
sp.l: Muſt I
Withdraw whilſt you diſcourſe?

sp.speaker: ALMANSOR.
sp.l: Yes, and be ſure
Thou fail not to prepare for me a conſort
Of Muſick.

sp.speaker: GAZVL.
sp.p: How a conſort, Sir, ſo late?

sp.speaker: GOMELLA.
sp.l: Oh! Sir,
How glad am I to ſee you heer again?

sp.speaker: ALMANSOR.
sp.l: My joy in ſeeing you is no leſſe great:
But ſpeak we of my mother.

sp.speaker: GOMELLA.
sp.l: Stay her comming;
To morrow without fail she arrives here
Vnknown.

sp.speaker: ALMANSOR.
sp.p:
Vnknown! and why dares she not to be ſee •
▪

sp.speaker: GOMELLA.
sp.p: The ſecret only you muſt know from her,

sp.speaker: ALMANSOR.
sp.l: How's this, Gomella, what can I imagine
In the uncertainty wherein you leave me?
I am aſtonished at this proceeding;
Your obſcure language is a cleer preſage
Of a conceal'd misfortune: Oh! my Siſter
Is dead, I need not doubt it.

sp.speaker: GOMELLA.
sp.l: Her death is not
The evill which should attriſt you.

sp.speaker: ALMANSOR.
sp.l: What, is't then
Hapned vnto her?

sp.speaker: ALMANSOR.
sp.l: That word is not ſufficient to cleer me:
Shall I not know why I receiv'd an order
To depart from Tremiſsa where I was
Brought up, to come with al ſpeed to theſe quarters,
T'addreſſe my ſelf to you with confidence,
To change my true name of Abencerage
Into that of Almanſor, and to have
A care not to reveale my family?

sp.speaker: GOMELLA
sp.l: Vpon this point I muſt shut up my mouth;
I'm not allowed to ſay more unto you.
It is you Mothers abſolute injunction,
And requeſt to me; have but patience
Vntill to morrow, when you shal be ſatisfied
From her own mouth; but the Sun, I perceive
Already groweth pale before the Moon.
Enter into my cot, and take with me
A poor repaſt.

sp.speaker: ALMANSOR.
sp.l: I doe deſire to be
Diſpens'd thereof now, if it pleaſeth you.

sp.speaker: ALMANSOR.
sp.l: Zegry expecteth me
On my engagement at his houſe to night.

sp.speaker: GOMELLA.
sp.l: Zegry, what ſay you, what charm doth oblige you
To anſwer ſo ill to Abencerage name,
To that debate, which for a thouſand reaſon
Is, between your two houſes, as it were,
Hereditary?

sp.speaker: ALMANSOR.
sp.l: A far juſter duty
Inviteth me to love him: but for him,
I'd loſt my life in Cairo, treacherous enemies
Encompaſſed me round, and had he not
Succoured me ſpeedily, I had been murthered
His name, which I knew well without diſcovering
Mine own, diſturb'd my new born amity;
But his, goodnes for me, his cares, his kindnes •
Soon diſſipated all thoſe old reſentements;
And ſo in order to the friendship which
Conjoined us, at laſt we came together
Into this country, where I was oblig'd
By the ſame frienship to lodge no where elſe
But at home with him.
GOM: Oh Heaven! but proceed.

sp.speaker: ALMANSOR.
sp.l: You know his Siſter: at firſt ſight of her,
I was her ſervant: by a powerfull charm
VVhoſe art she only knows, her fair eyes paid
But one look for the purchaſe of my heart;
And if the God of marriage. —

sp.speaker: GOMELLA.
sp.l: Soft, hold there.
Take heed you flatter not your ſelf with ſuch
A fatall hope, deſtroy your paſſions,
Or you deſtroy your honour.

sp.speaker: GOMELLA.
sp.l: Yes, Sir, your honour, what! doth this diſcourſe
Surpriſe and trouble you?

sp.speaker: ALMANSOR.
sp.l: I fear the name
Of an ingratefull perſon.

sp.speaker: GOMELLA.
sp.l: Fear that alſo
Of a low ſpirited one; theſe shamefull motion
Do wound your duty.

sp.speaker: GOMELLA.
sp.l: To morrow, when you ſee your Mother here,
You shall be ſatisfied, in the mean time,
Hate both the Siſter, and the brother.
ALM: Hate them?
I who have been ſo much oblig'd unto them?
No, no, I ſwear —
GOM: Swear not but let us enter;
Your mind will change, when you have heard th'adventure.

div.trailer: The end of the Second Act.

div.head: ACT III,

sp.speaker: ZEGRY.
sp.l: THe night approacheth, it is time to put
This letter with my hope into thy hands:
Work on her Slave, and act diſcreetly, that
She take this diamond from thee, afterward
Vſe all the skill thou haſt to know the ſecrets
Of her diſdainfull Miſtreſſe, and conſider
That I expect at thy return to hear
The ſentence of my life, or of my death.

sp.speaker: ORMIN.
sp.l: Cruell commandment, whereunto I ſee
My ſelf reduc'd! — aſide.
One word, Sir, ere I go.
Think well upon it yet, what hope have you?
Your importunities will increaſe her anger,
And you should do much better, If I durſt
To tell you ſo, henceforth to free your ſelf
Of this unworthy Empire; as love is
The price of love, ſo hate should alwaies be
The recompenſe of hate, and of contempt.
Your ſoul's are too ill ſuited to unite,
Love loſeth his power in Antipathies,
And tis an equall crime, Sir, in a contrary
Effect, to hate who Loves us, or to love
Who hates us.

sp.speaker: ZEGRY.
sp.l: Oh! ſpeak no more on 't unto me:
My evill's invincible, and my ſoul feels
Too ſenſibly the charms which doe deſtroy me;
To overcome my griefs, which have no equals
I ſeek ſome gentle ſuccour, and not counſel,
My chain, alas! is too ſtrong, and my heart
Too weak, as not to yeild unto the torrent
which carries me away.

sp.speaker: ORMIN.
sp.l: O rigorous Fate! — aſide.
But if all your indeavours ate in vain,
If fierce Fatima ſtill perſiſt in her
Former diſdains —

sp.speaker: ZEGRY.
sp.l: what pleaſure doſt thou take
T'increaſe my troubles? hide her rigours to me
And ſpeak but of her charms: my heart is try'd
By torments great enough, it need not be
afflicted with an evill not yet arriv'd.
flatter my weaknes, though therein thou shew
Thy ſelf leſſe faithfull, if thou doſt deſire
To intereſt thy ſelf in my misfortunes.

sp.speaker: ORMIN.
sp.l: Sir, if your eyes could penetrate into
The ſecrets of my heart, you would ſoon find
How great an intereſt I take in them,
And that if your lot lay within my power.
Your pleaſures should ſoon paſſe your hope, I call
The Prophet, ſo much honoured amongſt us,
To witnes, that I feel the counterſtroaks
Of all your troubles, that I'm grieved for them
Aſmuch as you, and tremble in like manner,
Laſtly that you are dearer to me far
Then you imagine, that my happines
Depends on the ſucceſſe of your amours,
And that it is for you alone my heart
Makes its devotions.

sp.speaker: ZEGRY.
sp.l: Grant it gracious Heaven
That thy zeal happily ſucceed in touching
In my behalf the ſoul of that ingratefull:
My ſiſter hath already been with her,
And I believe she hath not fail'd to ſpeak
To her for me, their friendship flatters me;
And gives me leave to hope that who eſteems
The ſiſter, may in time cherish the brother.
Adiew, perform thy duty, and return
With ſpeed to calm the tempeſts of my ſpirit.

sp.speaker: ORMIN.
sp.l: I will indeavour with permiſſion of
The holy Prophet, to hear ſuch ſucceſſe
As I deſire.

div.head: SCENE II.
div.l: WHereto shall I reſolve me in this ſad
Extremity? shall I ſollicit now
My Rivall gainſt my ſelf in the behalf
Of an ingratfull Maſter that doth wrong me?
And though he appeares blind to my diſadvantage,
Shall I approve my ſelf ſo more then he?
What shall I preſſe th'effect of what I fear?
Shall I give him content at my ſad coſt,
By a conſtraint ſo cruell? and shall I
Become my ſelf the faithfull Miniſter
Of the injuſtices which he doth do me?
No, no, let us not ſerve with ſo much heat
To trouble us yet with a new misfortune,
A perſon who coſt me ſo many tears:
If I muſt die, at leaſt let me not give
Arms for to peirce my heart; o'th contrary,
Let me act ſo, that he may hope for nothing
From fair Fatima, let me without ſcruple
Betray this falſe one, and deprive him of
A good which would become ſo fa'tal to me.
I should ground all the hope thats left unto me
Vpon the loſſe of his. But how is this,
That at theſe words I tremble with affright?
I find my heart already riſeth up
Againſt me in behalf of this falſe Maſter.
Alas! how cruel and perfidious
Soer he be, I cannot fail of faith
To wards him, but muſt love, and ſerve him truly.
'Tis ſo reſolv'd, my anger muſt give place
Vnto the love that raigneth in my boſom:
An ill example never juſtiſies
A crime: let us deliberate no more;
But what's the noiſe I hear? it is Fatima
That paſſeth, and Charifa follows her.

sp.speaker: FATIMA.
sp.l: THis foul contemps which Zaida offers me
Provokes me highly, fo far was this falſe one
From hindering Adibar to viſit her,
(As she engag'd herſelf in promiſe to me)
That she accepted kindly of his hand,
To diſoblige me; tis an injury
Of ſuch a nature as requires reveng.

sp.speaker: CHARIFA.
sp.l: The affront is known unto your ſelf, you ſaw it
With your own eyes, and to ſpeak truely Madame,
The injuſtice is extream.

sp.speaker: FATIMA.
sp.l: Know that my anget
Is ſo too; let us enter, it is late,
This night shall give us counſell.

sp.speaker: ORMIN.
sp.l: I'l go one,
And ſtay no longer, las! I dare not open
My mouth, nor keep it shut. Love, I beſeech thee,
Mingle at leaſt ſome good in the great maſſe.
Of my misfortunes, graunt that in demanding
All things of her, she grant me nothing for
him. — aſide.
Madame, shall I find ſo much goodnes from you
As to allow me the ſweet liberty
To leave this letter heer in your fair hands?
It commeth from a Louer the moſt paſſionate
Of all thoſe which the Luſtre of your eyes.
Hath made ſlaves; and who, not withſtanding all
The love where with his ſoul is ſeis'd, hath griven you
Some cauſe of plaint.

sp.speaker: FATIMA.
sp.l: Of plaint liſt Adibar
That writes vnto me? Softly to Charifa.

sp.speaker: CHARIFA.
sp.l: Without doubt tis he,
My heart doth tell me ſo.

sp.speaker: FATIMA.
sp.l: What would that falſe one
Deſire of me?

sp.speaker: ORMIN.
sp.l: How cruell is this ſweetnes
To me? — aſide.
The end of his deſires is to
Appear before you, highly to deteſt
His inſolēt crime, he would expreſſe the trouble
Wherewith his ſoul is preſs'd, to the Divinity
Iuſtly offended, and receive in making
His fault worthy to be forgot, a pardon.
Or death at your fair feet.

sp.speaker: FATIMA.
sp.l: I deſire not
His death; but I would have him live and hope;
How late ſoever his repentance comes,
I love it, and 't is welcome. My heart is
Already pacified by thy diſcourſe.

sp.speaker: ORMIN.
sp.p: I have for my misfortune, too well ſped. — aſide.

sp.speaker: FATIMA.
sp.l: Lets ſee with what, air, in this letter he
Vtters his thought, we will go in to read it,
And to give anſwer; ſince he is no longer
Obſtinate in his coldnes, I will ſend
His pardon ſign'd and ſeal'd.

sp.speaker: ORMIN.
sp.l: How full of joy
Will Zegry be at my return?

sp.speaker: ORMIN.
sp.l: Tis he that ſends me, he will kiſſe
The words where with y'ave flatter'd him.

sp.speaker: FATIMA.
sp.l: This is
My anſwer, go, and carry it unto him. — Exit Fatima.

sp.speaker: ORMIN.
sp.l: THis in equality aſtonisheth
And puzleth me, — Charifa!

sp.speaker: CHARIFA.
sp.l: I take no delight
To talk with fools

sp.speaker: CHARIFA.
sp.l: I have not the leiſure.
Adieu, fair prater!

sp.speaker: ORMIN.
sp.l: Be not ſo ungentle.
My hād shall ſpeak gould, to ſupply my mouth

sp.speaker: ORMIN.
sp.l: Believe the event.
From Zegry take this diamond.

sp.speaker: CHARIFA.
sp.l: To betraye,
And ſell my Miſtreſſe? God defend, I will not
Receive it.

sp.speaker: ORMIN.
sp.p: Be not ſuch a ſimple creature.

sp.speaker: CHARIFA.
sp.l: I take it then to pleaſe thee, but accept it
Vnto a good intent: the ſtone's not falſe,
At leaſt I think ſo:

sp.speaker: ORMIN.
sp.l: Thou mayſt be aſſur'd on't,
Tis very fair, and perfect.

sp.speaker: CHARIFA.
sp.l: Pardon me,
My words might ſeem t'imply a doubt, that I
Suſpected thee, but I am innocent.

sp.speaker: ORMIN.
sp.l: Wilt thou not tell me by what fatall errour
Thy miſtreſſe humour chang'd ſo ſuddenly?
And how it came, that only at the name
Of Zegry her heart preſently grew cold,
Although enflam'd with my diſcourſe before?

sp.speaker: CHARIFA.
sp.l: I love thee but too well; and if thou wilt
Be ſecret, I'l diſcover unto thee
This ſecret of importance, this hid miſtery.

sp.speaker: ORMIN.
sp.l: Thou wilt oblige me much, ſpeak, I'm diſcreet.
And will concea'lt as cloſely as thy ſelfe.

sp.speaker: CHARIFA.
sp.l: Fatima then loves Adibar aſmuch
As she doth hate thy Maſter; but for her,
Adibar by a pleaſant fair return
Hath no, leſſe coldnes then thy maſter love.
Thou knowſt that thou art not yet known of her,
And that love oftentimes troubleth the brain:
Hence was it, that at firſt she did believe
That Adibar ſent thee to ſpeak to her;
But ſince she knew her errour, she was mad;
I hear a noiſe, let us ſpeak ſoft I fear
We should be heard.

sp.speaker: ALABEZ.
sp.l: THe Devill! where thinks my Maſter
That I should meet with Ormin? it is night
And I can't find my way.

sp.speaker: ORMIN.
sp.l: Let me alone, thy honour is not much
In danger with me.

sp.speaker: CHARIFA.
sp.l: Foh! my diamond
Is fallen from my ſinger.

sp.speaker: ORMIN.
sp.l: Without doubt
The graſſe conceals it from our ſight.

sp.speaker: CHARIFA.
sp.l: We may
Seek it a good while ere we find it heer.

sp.speaker: ORMIN.
sp.p: Yes in this manner, I'le go fetch a light, Exit Ormin.

sp.speaker: CHARIFA.
sp.p: Return I've found it. — taking him for Ormin.

sp.speaker: ALABEZ.
sp.l: I should know that voice;
It is Charifa, ſtrange! what might she do
So late heer in theſe woods? I will approach
A little neerer. — aſide.

sp.speaker: CHARIFA.
sp.l: Thou but jeſts with me,
Kiſſe me no more, if thou doſt, I'l retire.

sp.speaker: ALABEZ:
sp.p: A rare piece this! I muſt hear all.

sp.speaker: CHARIFA.
sp.l: Yes really,
Promiſe me to be quiet, or I'l leave thee.
This is a little too much liberty
At firſt, I am a maid that ſtands upon
My reputation, and fear evill tongues,
I hold my honour very precious to me.

sp.speaker: ALABEZ.
sp.l: Thou ſeek'ſt to loſe it, and inviteſt him
To take it from thee. — aſide.

sp.speaker: CHARIFA.
sp.l: What thon ſpeakeſt not
A word unto me.

sp.speaker: CHARIFA.
sp.l: How doth thy heart ſigh, and thy cloſe mouth murmur?
Thoſe liberties, for all what I have ſaid,
May be excuſ'd, if thou will marry me;
Thou know'ſt that one muſt marry, to love well
And if I pleaſe thee. —

sp.speaker: ALABEZ.
sp.p: I am much ſurpriſ'd, by Heaven.

sp.speaker: CHARIFA.
sp.l: What! anſwereſt thou nothing? should this be
Through a contempt? I think that I'm not yet
So torn by time, as not to be thought worthy
To be conſidered; thou knoweſt well
Alabez, if I would have had that fellow.
My marriage with him had been already
Concluded, but that is a lowt, and hath not
The art to pleaſe me as thou haſt, his faults
Are more conſidered by me, then his ſervices.

sp.speaker: ALABEZ.
sp.p: The impudent jeers at me to my face.

sp.speaker: CHARIFA.
sp.l: That troubleſome never did any thing
Which pleaſed me, he hath a ſottish ſpirit,
And ſilly carriage; if the fool should marry me
I would not paſſe my word that he should not
Be one of thoſe which every one points at
With finger, which permit their neighbours to
Think their wives fair, ād which we commōly
Call cuckoulds.

sp.speaker: ORMIN.
sp.p: SEe heer, I have brought you light.

sp.speaker: CHARIFA.
sp.p: What have I done? this is a groſſe miſtake.

sp.speaker: ALABEZ.
sp.p: What think'ſt thou; have not I much cauſe to be
sp.l: Well ſatisfied? I have done nothing then
That ever pleaſ'd thee, I've a ſottish ſpirit
And ſilly carriage. Thou shouldſt die with shame.

sp.speaker: CHARIFA.
sp.p: Why? prethee? I have utteted but a truth.

sp.speaker: ALABEZ.
sp.l: But a truth, traitreſſe, o thou brazen face!
What! If I married thee, thou dangerous beaſt
I should be of the number of thoſe people
Which we call cuckoulds? thy impertinent tongue
Lied a hundred times, I'd rather chuſe
A rope then ſuch a bed fellow:

sp.speaker: ORMIN.
sp.l: Whence ſprings
Your quarrel?

sp.speaker: ALABEZ.
sp.l: Peace a while, I shall in good time
Talk with you, friend, companion of ill luck

sp.speaker: ORMIN.
sp.l: We muſt be gone, there's nothing to be gotten
But blows heer by a fool. — Exeunt Ormin and Charifa.

div.head: SCENE VIII.

sp.speaker: ALMANSOR.
sp.l: GOe ſee whence comes this noiſe.

sp.speaker: ALABEZ.
sp.l: Oh have I met thee, — giving Gaſul a buffett.
precious Apoſtle?

sp.speaker: ALABEZ.
sp.l: Pardon me,
I took thee for another, in good faith:
I ſought a ras kal that eſcaped me,
To whom I did intend that injury
But I shall ſoon o'r take him without running.

sp.speaker: ALMANSOR.
sp.p: Haſt learnt the cauſe of thoſe cōfuſed rumours?

sp.speaker: GASVL.
sp.l: No, but I have beene beaten by a perſon,
Who afterward made me excuſes for't.

sp.speaker: ALMANSOR.
sp.l: The houſe is not far of, give order to
The voices to advance, and bid them ſing
Neer to that Little wood.

div.stage: Adibar appearing on the other ſide:

sp.speaker: ADIAAR.
sp.l: See, friends, the place
Where Zasda dwels, if you are ready now.
Begin immediately.

l.hi: You whom I truſt with my ſad cares.

sp.speaker: GASVL.
sp.p: This voice belongs not to our company.

sp.speaker: ALMANSOR,
sp.l: This Stanza finish'd, let us be prepar'd
To ſing forthwith the ayr which I compoſ'd.

l.hi: You whom I trust with my ſad cares,
With all my deaths, and my deſpairs,

sp.l: You in whoſe boſomes I encloſe

l.hi: My love, my ſighs, my plaints, and wees:
To water and perfume theſe plains

sp.speaker: ADIBAR.
sp.l: What inſolēt voice troubles our confort heer.?
Th'affront shal not paſſe without punishment

l.hi: To water and perfume theſe plains
Vntill my tears their courſe have ſpent,
And my ſighs given my greeſs fult vent,
And winds breathe, as before, in pride.

sp.speaker: ADIBAR.
sp.p: Who art thou that dar'ſt heer to trouble me?

sp.speaker: ALMANSOR.
sp.l: My name is too well known to be conce • l'd.
I'm call'd Almanſor.

sp.speaker: ADIBAR.
sp.l: Fear, fear then mine anger.
I'm Adibar, thy greateſt Enemy
Who to meet thee, have made ſome weary ſteps

Vnto no purpoſe; now when leaſt ſought
〈…〉

I've found thee; tell me, how comes it
〈◊〉
Takeſt a licence to beſiege my Miſtreſſe
With ſo much inſolence? doſt viſit her,
As friend unto her brother, or as Lover
And ſervant unto her?

sp.speaker: ALMANSOR,
sp.l: Content thy ſelf
To underſtand that as the brothers friend,
The Siſter doth accept my ſetvices,
And that I reverence her: aſſure thy ſelf
That if I were ſo happy as to be
Her Lover, I should be diſcret enough,
Not to acquaint thee with it.

sp.speaker: ADIBAR.
sp.l: Theſe refinings,
And juglings which thou uſeſt to defend thee,
Cannot withdraw thee from my juſt revenge,
Thou shalt die.— Drawes

sp.speaker: ALMANSOR.
sp.l: Rather fear that my ſword heer — drawes.
Peircing thy heart, quēch thy love in thy blood.

sp.speaker: ZEGRY.
sp.l: FOr bear, and moderate this barbarous fury,
What means this, friends?

sp.speaker: ALMANSOR.
sp.l: This is not the Song
Which I deſire.

sp.speaker: ZEGRY.
sp.l: What cauſe, dear friend, could animate thee ſo?
Permit me, I beſeech you having parted you,
To reconcile you too at the ſame time:
I take an intereſt in your debats:
Let me know therfor what your differnce is.

sp.speaker: ADIBAR.
sp.l: Zegry in vaine you interpoſe your ſelf
To hinder the proceeding, my revengt
Is juſt, and your cares but prolong his life
For ſome few minures. — Exit Adibar.

sp.speaker: ZEGRY.
sp.l: DEare Almanſor tell me
Whence comes ſo ſtrong a hate between you two?
Relate the cauſe on't,

sp.speaker: ALMANSOR.
sp.l: Tis not worth the labour;
This petty difference which troubles thee,
Should be determined ere known.

sp.speaker: ZEGRY.
sp.l: In vain
Thon doſt perſiſt to hide this ſecret from me:
Almanſor, I gheſſe at it; ſure, ſome Beauty
Embroils you; I've heard heer two different conſorts.
The reſt I do divine.

sp.speaker: ALMANSOR.
sp.l: Friend, I confeſſe it;
We both at one time gave our Evering Muſick
To one and the ſame Miſtreſſe.

sp.speaker: ZEGRY.
sp.l: May not I
Know her name, Friend?

sp.speaker: ALMANSOR.
sp.l: Heavens how am I put to ▪t?
Should I tell him that I adore his ſiſter? — aſide.

sp.speaker: ZEGRY.
sp.l: Friend, this reſervednes ſuits not that name,
I did not hide my amours for Fatima
From thee.

sp.speaker: ALMANSOR.
sp.l: He hath already promiſed
His ſiſter; I'm confounded; if I dare
To name her, what will he not ſay? — aſide.

sp.speaker: ZEGRY.
sp.l: This confuſ'd ſilence should ſufficiently
Inſtruct me that he doth adore Fatima,
And dares not tell it me — aſide.
What! shall I not
Know then what object hath ſubjected thee?

sp.speaker: ALMANSOR.
sp.l: Her fair name uttered would make us enemies,
Inſtead of doing thee a courteſy
Diſpenſe me to ſay more on't.

sp.speaker: ZEGRY.
sp.l: How is this!
Wilt thou not go unto my houſe?

sp.speaker: ALMANSOR
sp.l: Exouſe me,
This night I am engag'd by promiſe to
Lodge at Gomella's.

sp.speaker: ALMANSOR.
sp.l: Yes, I fear that he ſtays for me, adiew,
I'ue promiſed him, and I can't fail my word. Exit Almanſor.

sp.speaker: ZEGRY
sp.l: The traitor Loves Fatima: and intends
To marry her: to judge on't otherwiſe,
Is to abuſe my ſelf; yes owing me,
His life, he makes uſe of it to deſtroy me;
But he that could ſave it, can alſo ruine it;
And his death loudly shall proclaime to all
That the ſame arm which ſerves the innocent,
Can punish the ingratefull inſolent.

div.trailer: The End of the third Act.

div.head: ACT IV.

sp.speaker: ALMANSOR.
sp.l: YOu shal not go alone to meet my mother,
I ▪l follow you, Gomella.

sp.speaker: GOMELLA
sp.l: That needs not
Her order doth oblige you to expect her
Here at my houſe.

sp.speaker: ALMANSOR.
sp.l: But nature doth impoſe
A ſtronger law upon me.

sp.speaker: GOMELLA.
sp.l: Sir she hath not
Vnderſtood of your comming yet, your ſight
Will be too ſudden a ſurpriſe, for bear
Till I acquaint her with it.

sp.speaker: ALMANSOR
sp.l: I expect
No blame in this encounter; If I should
Surpriſe her, it would be delightfully:

sp.speaker: GOMELLA.
sp.p: Seeing you will, let's go together then.

sp.speaker: ALMANSOR.
sp.p: I do but what I ought.

sp.speaker: ALMANSOR.
sp.l: Zegry comes forth his houſe; before I go,
I muſt embrace him.

sp.speaker: GOMELLA.
sp.p: Stay, you may not do it.

sp.speaker: ALMANSOR.
sp.l: Conſtraint's unjuſt, as much as it is cruell:
Ought I to fly a friend ſo dear, ſo faithfull?
Suffer me to ſpeak to him, and I'l follow you
Immediately.

sp.speaker: GOMELLA.
sp.l: I cannot, for I have an expreſſe order
Vnto the contrary. — Exeunt.

sp.speaker: ZEGRY.
sp.l: ORmin, did'ſt thou obſerve how carefully
That traitor shun'd me aſſoon as he ſaw me?
Did'ſt mark how he was troubled at firſt,
How he advanc'd, a ſtep or two to Wards me,
And then went back again, how he reſign'd
The place unto me in confuſion,
Preſs'd with the ſtings of his ingratitude?

sp.speaker: ORMIN.
sp.l: What ever I obſerved, it can never
Enter into my thought Almanſor should
Be guilty of ſo baſe and black a crime;
And though in shew I find him culpable,
I eſteem him incapable to commit
Any baſe act; he ſtill appear'd vnto me
A perſon of much honour, and too jealous
Thereof, ſo ill t'imploy the life which he
Holdeth of you: beſides I find within me
A certain ſecret inſtinct which I
Can't comprehend, that when I should accuſe him,
Forceth me to defend him.

sp.speaker: ZEGRY.
sp.l: Seeing me
To cheris'h that too much belov'd Ingratefull,
Thou art accuſtom'd alſo to careſſe him.
I can't believe, neither that he betrays me,
Nor can I doubt ont, that's my punishment.
And thoſe ſweet motions, which I ſcarce can banish,
Aggravate his offence, inſtead of leſſening it:
Iudge then how much I am to be lamented
In this condition, the onely good
That reſts to me, is to fear nothing more.
Fortune would not afflict me heer by halfs;
I loſe a Miſtreſſe, and a friend together:
Both injure me, and I have ſo much weaknes,
That I can't hate the Miſtreſſe, nor the Friend;
But could'ſt thou yeſterday learn from Charifa
Why fair Fatima hath ſo much contempt
Within her boſome for me? thou haſt told me
That Adibar doth charm her, but thou haſt not
Tould me from whence her hatred doth proceed.

sp.speaker: ORMIN.
sp.l: Fatima, if I may believe what hath
Been told me, alwaies did abhore you for
Vnfaithfullnes, she hath ſome reaſon to
Believe you falſe, and this is that as far
As I can underſtand, which doth oblige her
To be ſo cruell to you.

sp.speaker: ZEGRY.
sp.l: Falſe, ſayſt thou?
I never was ſo.

sp.speaker: ORMIN.
sp.l: She hath underſtood though,
That a maid call'd Zelinda, faire enough,
Very young, and of an illuſtrious family,
And who received ſometime many ſervices
From you, being almoſt on the point to ſee you
Her husband, and when all things were diſpoſ'd
And ready for the mariage was fouly
For ſaken by you and deſpis'd; it ſeems
That this example toucheth, and doth teach her
That who can once, can chāge a thouſād times.

sp.speaker: ZEGRY.
sp.p: Ormin, this change is no inconſtancy.

sp.speaker: ORMIN.
sp.p: It would be very hard to prove it innocent:

sp.speaker: ZEGRY.
sp.l: VVithout doubt this pretended mariage
Made a great noiſe; but I wil tell thee all

sp.speaker: ORMIN.
sp.l: VVhat will th'ing ratefull ſay? — aſide

sp.speaker: ZEGRY:
sp.l: Before that mariage was concluded which
VVas to unite us to Abencerage blood,
And by that means at laſt to quench the heat
Of an old hatred, fair Fatima was
Already Miſtreſſe of my heart; to make me
Take a new chain, Zelinda, whō they offered me
In my opinion, was not fair enough:
So that I ſaw her without loving her:
Her feeble Beauty could not shake the fetters
VVhich tied me, yet I indeavoured
To have ſom kindnes for her, but her eyes
Or my heart were not ſtrong enoug to work it;
And if I did her any ſervices,
It was but in deſign to pleaſe my parents:
Fatima there fore is to blame to think
That I am falſe: ſince I had never love
For any but for her.

sp.speaker: ORMIN.
sp.l: Alas! I need not
Doubt more of his contempt! I was inquiſitive
To know too much, and now I doe repent it. — aſide.

sp.speaker: ZEGRY.
sp.l: This is a truth, which eaſily can bee ptov'd?
But how comes it my ſiſter, sup ſo ſoon?

sp.speaker: ZAIDA,
sp.l: Brother, have you receiv'd th' intelligence
Is given me of the death of him which was
Deſigned for my husband?

sp.speaker: ZEGRY.
sp.l: Yes, I've heard it;
It is too true, he died in Argier
O'th ſpotted feaver.

sp.speaker: ZAIDA.
sp.l: I'm unhappy by it;
But you are neer your ioy, and may diſcourſe
Of mariage and love.

sp.speaker: ZEGRY.
sp.l: Oh, Siſter, rather
Say that I muſt no longer now diſcourſe
Of love nor Mariage: ſay that I muſt punish
A baſe and an ingratefull ſpirit with death
One that hath wickedly betray'd my friēdship:
Fury alone preſides now in my ſoul,
And I muſt think nor ſpeak of any thing
But of destroying a perfidious wretch.

sp.speaker: ZAIDA.
sp.l: Who is that traitor? let me know, I pray you,
What ſignall crime provoketh you ſo highly.

sp.speaker: ZEGRY.
sp.l: Thou know'ſt too well the Authour of my injury
His name's Almanſor, his love is his crime,

sp.speaker: ZEGRY.
sp.l: Siſter, tis too true.
His inſolent love hath ſtirred up mine anger.

sp.speaker: ZAIDA.
sp.l: He knoweth that Almanſor loveth me,
And that is it enrageth him. — aſide.

sp.speaker: ZEGRY.
sp.l: His death,
Is juſt, add he shall die, baſe, and ingratefull!

sp.speaker: ZAIDA.
sp.l: Brother, you should examine without paſſion
All that which might be of a friend ſuſpected,
And we should never judge of his offence
But with much care and much indulgence: alwaies
Almanſor htth appear'd too generous
To mingle any foul or unjuſt thing
In his affections; and he oweth you
Too much, to have a thought to wrong a friēd
That ſav'd his life.

sp.speaker: ZEGRY.
sp.l: Siſter, thou doſt oblige me;
Thy arguments with little contradiction
Diſarm all my reſentments quite; Almanſor
Is ſo dear to me, that how ere he wrongs me,
Thou wilt do me a coutteſie, to ſtop
My anger.

sp.speaker: ZAIDA.
sp.p: Perhaps, you have accuſed him unjuſtly.

sp.speaker: ZEGRY.
sp.l: Would that it pleaſed Heaven I were abus'd!
But alas! my ſuſpition is too juſt,
I'l tell't thee now; he loveth

sp.speaker: ZAIDA.
sp.l: How! should he love Fatima? really
That crime is black:

sp.speaker: ZEGRY.
sp.l: The better to aſſure thee on't, tis beſt
Thou go to viſſit her, I do believe
Thou'lt vnderſtand frō her that he adores her,
And that he's falſe to me.

sp.speaker: ZAIDA.
sp.l: Trāitor! Inconſtant!
Pernitious Spirit!

sp.speaker: ZEGRY.
sp.l: But, Siſter, VVhy appear you
So troubled in your eyes and countenance?

sp.speaker: ZAIDA.
sp.l: The trouble of mine eyes cleerly denotes
That my heart feels the evils which your friend doth you,
Your friēd, what haye I ſaid? that name ſuits ill
With his condition, if he be your Rivall,
He's not your friend. Goe perſently to quench
His life and Love, and wash away the crimes
Of his ſoul in his blood.

sp.speaker: ZEGRY.
sp.l: No, Siſter, no;
We should examine without paſſion
All that which might be of a friend ſuſpected,
And one should never judge of his offence
But with much care and much indulgence; alwaies
Almansor hath appear'd too generous,
To mingle any foul, or vnjuſt thing
In his affections; and he oweth me
Too much, to have a thought to wrōg a friēd
That ſau'd his life.

sp.speaker: ZAIDA.
sp.p: In what an errour are you?

sp.speaker: ZEGRY.
sp.l: If I am in an errour, I receiv'd it
From you: theſe were your ſentiments, good Siſter,
And shall be mine.

sp.speaker: ZAIDA.
sp.l: Then knew I not his crime;
But now that it is plain, take your revenge,
I will no more reſtrain you.

sp.speaker: ZEGRY.
sp.l: Stop me rather;
Condemn my anger, not my amity.
In favour of Almanſor I would be
Abus'd; I will accuſe him, but I would
That others should excuſe him, I ſpeak of
Revenge, but ſeek it not, and threaten only
But to the end to have my arme reſtrain'd.
His paſſion, perhaps, may be condemn▪d
Vnjuſtly: poſſibly i • might be born.
Before our friendship, and, perhaps Fatima
Anſwereth unto it, and that to unite them,
Gomellas orders do invite him heer;
If it be ſo, to free my ſelf from crime,
Siſter, tis juſt I yeild Fatima to him:
I'l break my chains, and with a ſetled heart
Will make the pleaſures of my friend mine own.

sp.speaker: ZAIDA.
sp.l: what ſtrange abuſe, what ſeeret charm thus ſoftens
Your heart in the behalf of an Ingratefull:
He owes his life unto you: ought he not
T'acquit him ſelf to wards you by all poſſible
Indeavours? if he be our Rivall, can you
Without much weaknes tamely give him up
Your Miſtreſſe? if he be your friend, as you
Eſteem him, ought he not to give you up
The object which you love.

sp.speaker: ZEGRY.
sp.l: Without reply
Go preſently to viſit fair Fatima:
And fail not fully to inform your ſelf
Of their intelligence. — Exit Zegry.

sp.speaker: MEDINA.
sp.l: YOu aſtonish me;
I can't conceive how one can love a man,
And preſſe his death.

sp.speaker: ZAIDA.
sp.l: Oh! ſay not that I love
Such an ingratefull and inconſtant wretch:
Believe that if I have fires, they are fires
Of rage, and that my heart will ne'r be qui ••
Till this perfidious Lover be a ſacrifice
To my juſt anger.

sp.speaker: ZAIDA.
sp.l: True, I weep, Medina:
If that falſe one should perish, I should die;
I feel that rage and tendernes, hate and love
Triumph by Turns within me: I'm his Enemy
And yet I am his Lover, when my anger
Encreaſeth, th'other Kinder paſſion ſprings:
And though that he be louely, and hath falſely
Betray'd me, I can neither love, nor hate him

sp.speaker: MEDINA.
sp.l: Madam, ſpeak ſofter, you will elce be heard.
Adibar comes to wards us.

sp.speaker: ADIBAR.
sp.p: Zaida, where go you with my heart?

sp.speaker: ZAIDA.
sp.l: I pray you,
Leave me alone, and do not trouble me,
Adieu.

sp.speaker: ZAIDA,
sp.l: • have
• o need of them.

sp.speaker: ZAIDA.
sp.p: You muſt excuſe me, I have other buſines.

sp.speaker: ADIBAR.
sp.l: With a look onely, conſolate my griefs;
• is you I ſeek.

sp.speaker: ZAIDA.
sp.p: And tis you that I fly.

sp.speaker: ADIBAR.
sp.p: How! treat you ſuch a faithfull I over ſo?

sp.speaker: ZAIDA.
sp.p: Fatima there will be leſſe cruell to you.

sp.speaker: ADIBAR.
sp.l: Mock not at her, Fatima is as fair,
Although leſſe proud then you.

sp.speaker: FATIMA.
sp.l: VVHat Adibar
Still with this ſcornfull? my revenge is juſt.
'Tis time that it break forth. Zaida, I find you
In ſuch a black and heavy melancholy,
That I loſe the deſign which brought me hither:
Shall I dare ſpeak of dances, revels, feaſts,
And of a mariage in the condition
Wherein you are?

sp.speaker: ZAIDA.
sp.p: What ſay you, of a mariage?

sp.speaker: FATIMA.
sp.l: Since you preſſe me,
You shall know all; know that my Father ha •
Provided one for me.

sp.speaker: FATIMA.
sp.p: Yes, Zaida, and she bufimes is well forwar •

sp.speaker: ZAIDA.
sp.l: In your contents I claim an intereſt:
I should be glad to know your Lovers name.

sp.speaker: FATIMA.
sp.l: He's an accomplish▪d man, noble, and bra ••

And of a charming preſence, and rare meri •
▪
I doubt not but you will approve the choice
My Father hath made of him.

sp.speaker: ZAIDA.
sp.l: How she makes me
Languish to meet death? — aſide.
Well, who is the man?

sp.speaker: FATIMA.
sp.l: You know him very well;
He made long time his ordinary reſidence
At home with you; your brother Zegrys frie ••
Have I yet ſaid ynough?

sp.speaker: FATIMA,
sp.p: Divine you not that he is call'd Almanſor!

sp.speaker: ZAIDA.
sp.p: I can no more, but faint and die. — aſide.

sp.speaker: FATIMA
sp.l: How she
Is chang▪d, she feels my pain, and I'm reveng'd

sp.speaker: ADIBAR.
sp.p: I have much intereſt in this event.

sp.speaker: ZAIDA.
sp.p: This match without doubt cannot chuſe but pleaſe you.

sp.speaker: FATIMA.
sp.l: True, I am not of thoſe who through a maxime
Of I know not, what modeſty, blush at mariage
As if it were a crime, feign to ſigh at it,
And yet in ſecret are ſad at the heart,
If it should not be conſummate. I aſſure you.
Vpon this point I not diſſemble with you:
I no way hate the Lover that▪s deſign'd me,
I prize his love, his ſervices, his merit
At a high rate, and if he loves me much,
He is no leſſe belov'd.

sp.speaker: ZAIDA.
sp.l: It ſeemeth then,
He loves you very much.

sp.speaker: FATIMA.
sp.l: I can't expreſſe it:
He lives but for me, breatheth but for me:
I am the ſole original of his good
Or evill fortune when he ſees me not,
He is in torments, and when hazard bring me
Vnto his ſight, again, I have great cauſe
To fear that he might die with ſudden joy;
Laſtly if any truth be in his oaths,
All other beauties are contemptible to him.

sp.speaker: ZAIDA.
sp.l: Oh Heaven! what hear I, where am I? oh traitor!
Ingratefull wretch! — aſide.
But could you ſo ſoon love him
Before yov knew him?

sp.speaker: FATIMA.
sp.l: I cannot be blam▪d
For this quick love, I ſaw in him at firſt
All things that might induce a maid to love
Beſides heerein I execute the order
My Father doth ordain, I willingly
Obey his will; and ſince he hath choſen him
For ſon in law and for ſupport, I think
That he is worthy of it, and conform
My ſelf unto him.

sp.speaker: ZAIDA.
sp.l: But what are your thoughts
Of Adibar?

sp.speaker: ADIBAR.
sp.l: I dare not to pretend
To her paſſ'd goodneſs more.

sp.speaker: FATIMA.
sp.l: He deſerv'd not
The honour of my love; he changed firſt,
And I change at my turn.

sp.speaker: ZAIDA.
sp.l: He was not alwaies
Vnworthy to pleaſe you; can you forget him.

sp.speaker: FATIMA.
sp.l: Yes, and with much juſtice, and reaſon too,
He is to me the moſt ingratefull perſon
Vpon the earth; his contempt was unjuſt,
But mine is not ſo. Let us ceaſe to ſpeak
Of that inconſtant Lover; I will pay him
Hatred for hatred, contempt for contempt.
Let us again talk of our mariage,
And let me know if I may have the honour
To ſee you there,

sp.speaker: ZAIDA.
sp.l: Excuſe me, I'm oppreſſ▪d
With a great pain, which is redoubled
Since your diſcourſe, ſo that I'm rendered
Incapable to be preſent there, and am
Inforc'd to quit you at this very inſtant.

sp.speaker: ADIBAR
sp.l: I wait you; ſuffer me to pay the ſervice
I owe you. — He leads her by the arm?

sp.speaker: ZAIDA,
sp.l: I am forced through my weaknes
To accept your ſupport. — Exeunt Zaida & Adibar

sp.speaker: FATIMA,
sp.l: ZAida feels my diſcaſe, but Adibar
Flies me: herein my revenge is compleat,
Though my hope be deſtroyd.

sp.speaker: CHARIFA.
sp.l: You have loſt nothing
By that, Almanſor's worth a thouſand of him

sp.speaker: FATIMA.
sp.l: Iudge better of my plaint, what I have ſaid
Is but a fiction; I perceive Medina
And thou are intimate, she could not chuſe
But tell thee that Almanſor's very dear
To the ingratefull Zaida, this I heard
From thy own mouth.

sp.speaker: FATIMA.
sp.l: This deviſe of mine,
In feigning that Almanſor was to marry me,
Is to revenge me of her for admitting,
Contrary to her promiſe, my falſe Lover
To addreſſe courtship to her, and to punish her
For the evills which she hath procured me.

sp.speaker: CHARIFA.
sp.p: How cunning are you! this deceit is notable.

sp.speaker: FATIMA.
sp.p: HOw! quit ſo ſoon the object of your heart?

sp.speaker: ADIBAR.
sp.p: I ſtudied more her reſt then my content.

sp.speaker: FATIMA.
sp.l: You appear ſeiſed with an extream ſadnes.

sp.speaker: ADIBAR.
sp.l: I cannot ſee that ſuffer which I love
Without grief.

sp.speaker: ADIBAR.
sp.l: My reſpect only put me of, and not
Her cruelty,

sp.speaker: FATIMA.
sp.l: If she were juſt, or generous
She would deſpiſe a lover that's unſaithfull.

sp.speaker: ADIBAR.
sp.p: I were to blame, if I should complain of her.

sp.speaker: FATIMA.
sp.p: Almanſers fortune is more ſweet with me.

sp.speaker: ADIBAR.
sp.p: I'm to well ſatisfied, to be jealous of it.

sp.speaker: FATIMA.
sp.l: You do but flatter you with a vain hope,
Zaida hath but diſdain, and hate for you.

sp.speaker: ADIBAR.
sp.l: Her hate and her diſdain are ended now;
And our hearts ſpeedily shall be united
By mariage.

sp.speaker: FATIMA.
sp.l: But Sir, you may be miſtaken
In your accompt, and hope; do you not know
That Zaida's promiſ'd?

sp.speaker: ADIBAR.
sp.l: Rather you may be
Deceived in this point: perhaps you know not
That he who was to marry her, is dead.

sp.speaker: ADIBAR.
sp.l: Yes Madam, and fair Zaida
Propitious at laſt, will render juſtice
To my devout affection, and did
Aſſure me when I took my leave of her
That she would marry me, if I could get
Her brother to conſent unto't; adiew;
To obtain this ſo dear and pretious Beauty,
I muſt addreſſe me to her brother, and
Solicit my beſt friends. — Exit Adibar.

sp.speaker: FATIMA.
sp.l: WHat have I done?
Alas! my fiction hath only ſerv▪d
To diſpoſe Zaida to deprive me of
My Lover.

sp.speaker: FATIMA.
sp.l: Leave me; in a fate
So ſad as this, every thing hurts, deſtroyes,
And makes me deſperate.

sp.speaker: FATIMA.
sp.l: No, I hear nothing but the fury which
Raigns in my confef'd ſpirits, grief ſeiſeth me
And anger doth tranſport me.

sp.speaker: FATIMA.
sp.l: Oh that I were dead! ceaſe to comfort me
In ſuch a juſt deſpair put me to bed,
Or in my grave there to lye buried.

div.trailer: The End of the fourth Act.

sp.speaker: GOMELLA.
sp.l: YOu ſee the cote where I make my abode.

sp.speaker: LINDARACHE.
sp.l: Sir, if you pleaſe, I shall defire to be
Private a while here with my ſon, and preſently
I'm yours.

sp.speaker: ALMANSOR.
sp.l: Oh Madam, oh dear Mother,
In this bleſt time shal I obtain the honour
Of your embracements?

sp.speaker: LINDERACHE.
sp.l: Stay, Abencerage,
Know our dishonour firſt, and shew thy ſelf
My ſon before I embrace thee, I was mother
Of two fair children, when a Ravisher
Stole away both my Daughter, and thy Siſter.

sp.speaker: ALMANSOR.
sp.p: Good God! what do you tell me?

sp.speaker: LINDARACHE
sp.l: That thy Siſter
Is ravished.

sp.speaker: ALMANSOR.
sp.l: Name but the Ravisher,
And he is dead.

sp.speaker: LINDERACHE.
sp.l: Come, now embrace me, Son, this ſaying makes me
Believe that Heaven hath given thee me for to
Revenge me.

sp.speaker: ALMANSOR.
sp.l: Let me know his name, I ſwear
By th' holy Prophet, that his blood shal wash
The injury, and that this arm of mine
Shall ſacrifice him in ſtautly unto you.

sp.speaker: LINDARACHE
sp.l: Thou shall know all, hearken, and let me ſpeak:
Thou art not ignorant of the enmity.
which raign'd for many ages twixt the houſes
O'th' Zegries, and of the Abencerages:
Now thou muſt know that on th' opinion
Conceived that a mariage would put end
To this contention, my daughter was
Deſign'd for wife to Zegry; every thing
Was ready, and the day appointed, when
Through an averſion, or rather through
Contempt, the trecherous Zegry flying our
Alliance, haſtily embark'ed himſelf
For Argser: and to add unto our griefs,
Aſſoon as this report was ſpread, my daughter
Was ſeen no more.

sp.speaker: ALMANSOR.
sp.l: O Heaven! who should be cauſe
Of this misfortune?

sp.speaker: LINDERACHE.
sp.l: Read this letter heer,
It will inform thee fully

body.head: LETTER.
body.l: YOu, from whom, I receiv'd my breath,
Know that a ſad fate worſe then death
